qas.question: How many research institutes does the university run on campus?

What is the name of the museum and research center for Near Eastern studies, that is owned by the university?
What lab does the university have a joint stake in?
Where is the Apache Point Observatory located?

context: The university operates <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2><b5_0>12<b5_0/><a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/> research institutes and <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>113<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/> research centers on campus. Among these are <a2_0><a2_2>the <a2_1><b7_0>Oriental Institute<b7_0/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>—a museum and research center for Near Eastern studies owned and operated by the university—and a number of National Resource Centers, including the Center for Middle Eastern Studies. Chicago also operates or is affiliated with a number of research institutions apart from the university proper. The university partially manages Argonne National Laboratory, part of the United States Department of Energy's national laboratory system, and has a joint stake in <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>Fermilab<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>, a nearby particle physics laboratory, as well as a stake in the Apache Point Observatory in <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>Sunspot, New Mexico<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>. Faculty and students at the adjacent Toyota Technological Institute at Chicago collaborate with the university, In 2013, the university announced that it was affiliating the formerly independent Marine Biological Laboratory in <b8_0>Woods Hole<b8_0/>, Mass. Although formally unrelated, the National Opinion Research Center is located on <b9_0>Chicago's campus<b9_0/>.
